docs.snippet: Denmark, making a sensational World Cup debut, used the attacking skills of Preben Elkjaer and Michael Laudrup to beat Uruguay, 6-1, today and become the second team to advance to the second round of the soccer championship.   Elkjaer registered the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Denmark, making a sensational World Cup debut, used the attacking skills of Preben Elkjaer and Michael Laudrup to beat Uruguay, 6-1, today and become the second team to advance to the second round of the soccer championship. Elkjaer registered the first three-goal game in the 24-team tournament as the Danes joined Brazil, which also won its first two games, as second-round qualifiers. In other games today, West Germany, which stands second in Group E with 3 points, beat Scotland, 2-1, and Belgium withstood a physical match with Iraq to win, 2-1, in Group B. There can be no questions now about the Danes' offense, as creative as any in the world. Against Uruguay, one of South America's best teams, Elkjaer and Laudrup, both of whom are stars on Italian clubs, were unstoppable.

docs.snippet: THE Uruguayan prison for political prisoners is called - in the logic of authoritarianism - Libertad (Liberty).   At first Libertad seems the model prison that the people who run it claim it to be. It's neat and clean and runs on schedule, like...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Uruguayan prison for political prisoners is called - in the logic of authoritarianism - Libertad (Liberty). At first Libertad seems the model prison that the people who run it claim it to be. It's neat and clean and runs on schedule, like Mussolini's trains. There are strict rules, but then every prison must have rules or it wouldn't be a prison, and Libertad isn't a country club.

headline.main: FILM: 'EYES OF THE BIRDS' DEPICTS URUGUAYAN JAIL

docs.snippet: In the nightclub of one of the large hotels here, a group of Brazilian dancers and musicians perform every night before enthusiastic crowds of Mexicans.   The crowd there last Friday night, after Brazil's soccer team had won its World Cup game that...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the nightclub of one of the large hotels here, a group of Brazilian dancers and musicians perform every night before enthusiastic crowds of Mexicans. The crowd there last Friday night, after Brazil's soccer team had won its World Cup game that day, had come not so much to watch the show but to bask in the ambience - to be Brazilian for a while. Brazil had clinched a berth in the second round of the World Cup by squeezing past Algeria, and Guadalajarans were delirious with happiness. Young people celebrated with a game called ''How Many Mexican Youths with How Many Brazilian Flags Can Be Squeezed into One Volkswagen Beetle?''

byline.original: By WILLIAM STOCKTON, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Brazil and Spain registered 3-0 victories today in the World Cup, and the results helped determine all but the final participant for the second round of the tournament.   In Guadalajara, the Brazilians eliminated Northern Ireland and its 41-year-old...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil and Spain registered 3-0 victories today in the World Cup, and the results helped determine all but the final participant for the second round of the tournament. In Guadalajara, the Brazilians eliminated Northern Ireland and its 41-year-old goalie, Pat Jennings, as the three-time winners of soccer's biggest prize finished their round-robin play with three victories in three games without conceding a goal. Spain got two goals from Ramon Caldere and topped Algeria in Monterey in the other Group D contest, eliminating the North Africans from the 24-team tournament.

docs.snippet: If there was any doubt about Danish Dynamite, it vanished today in this historic city on the highland plains. Starting 10 players who make their living in leagues outside their homeland, and participating in its first World Cup, Denmark defeated West...
docs.lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt about Danish Dynamite, it vanished today in this historic city on the highland plains. Starting 10 players who make their living in leagues outside their homeland, and participating in its first World Cup, Denmark defeated West Germany, 2-0, to capture Group E. Called ''El Grupo de la Muerte'' -the Group of Death - because it was believed to be the strongest of the six groups in the first round, today it produced a vibrant match between two teams that had already qualified for the second round. By joining Brazil as the only teams to win all three first-round games, the Danes got to stay ''home'' in Queretaro, famous as the home of La Corregidora, the heroine in the struggle for independence of 1810, and also as the site of the execution of the Austrian puppet king, Maximilian, in 1867. Today's game decided the opponents for the second round. The Danes will play Spain, the second-place team in Group D, here next Wednesday while the West Germans will play Morocco, the surprising winner of Group F. There was some question whether Spain, with its strong tradition of soccer, was a less desirable opponent than Morocco, the first African team ever to reach the second round of the World Cup. But the latter game will be in Monterrey, hotter and at much lower altitude than the West Germans have been experiencing.

byline.original: By GEORGE VECSEY, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Hermann Neuberger, vice president of FIFA, soccer's governing body, banned Omar Borras, the Uruguayan coach, from his team's bench for the next game in the World Cup tournament because of rough play in the opening round. Uruguay, the South American...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hermann Neuberger, vice president of FIFA, soccer's governing body, banned Omar Borras, the Uruguayan coach, from his team's bench for the next game in the World Cup tournament because of rough play in the opening round. Uruguay, the South American champion, was fined 25,000 Swiss francs (about $12,000).

docs.snippet: World Cup organizers said today that more than 1.3 million persons attended the 36 matches of the soccer tournament's first round, an average of about 38,000 a game.   The organizing committee still did not have official attendance figures for...
docs.lead_paragraph: World Cup organizers said today that more than 1.3 million persons attended the 36 matches of the soccer tournament's first round, an average of about 38,000 a game. The organizing committee still did not have official attendance figures for Friday's Scotland-Uruguay match, but said the other 35 games attracted 1,364,766 fans.

docs.snippet: On a recent trip to Egypt President Julio Maria Sanguinetti asked the manager of the Hotel Luxor where the hotel bought its beef.   ''He said it was imported from France, at a price that almost made me faint,'' said Mr. Sanguinetti, whose country's...
docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Egypt President Julio Maria Sanguinetti asked the manager of the Hotel Luxor where the hotel bought its beef. ''He said it was imported from France, at a price that almost made me faint,'' said Mr. Sanguinetti, whose country's No. 1 export is beef. ''It was about a third of what the meat would have cost in Europe.'' At the same time, he said, the United States is offering beef to Brazil, Uruguay's northern neighbor, for half what it would cost in the United States.

headline.main: URUGUAYAN VISITS U.S. WITH TRADE AS TOP ISSUE

byline.original: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to the New York Times
